intro: Alchornea occidentalis, commonly known as West Indian mallow, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central and South America. It is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 5 meters tall, featuring alternate, ovate to elliptical leaves with a rough texture. The plant produces showy yellow flowers that are clustered in terminal panicles, often blooming during the rainy season. Its fruits are capsule-like structures that release small, hairy seeds when mature. Alchornea occidentalis is adapted to tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in disturbed soils and coastal areas.
